contextId.quote: I will harden the Egyptians' hearts

contextId.information: Each of the occurrences of "Israel" refer to the people of Israel. AT: "the people of Israel" or "the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Joshua represents the Israelites that he led into battle. AT: "So Joshua and the men he chose fought against the Amalekites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

The words "Israel" and "Amalek" represent the fighters from those groups. AT: "the Israelite fighters were winning ... the Amalekite fighters would begin to win" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Israel was winning ... Amalek would begin to win

contextId.information: Here "heart" refers to the person bringing the offering. AT: "everyone who is willing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: all of you who have a willing heart

contextId.information: Here "hearts" refers to the women. The hearts of the women who responded to God are spoken of as if they were water stirred up by a storm.  AT: "who responded to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "heart" refers to the people. AT: "who was willing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "heart" refers to Bezalel. The ability to teach is spoken of as if it something that could be placed in a heart.  AT: "He gave Bezalel the ability to teach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He has put it in his heart to teach

contextId.information: Here "mind" refers to the person who was made skillful by Yahweh. AT: "to whom Yahweh had given skill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: in whose mind Yahweh had given skill

contextId.information: Here "heart" refers to the person. The heart that responded to God is spoken of as if it were water stirred up by a storm.  AT: "who responded to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
